required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Altis® Single Incision Sling System for Female Stress Urinary Incontinence Study
clinical_study.official_title: The Altis® Single Incision Sling System for Female Stress Urinary Incontinence Study

brief_summary.textblock: An international, multi-center, single arm, prospective clinical study designed to assess the safety and efficacy of the Coloplast Altis single incision sling system for females with stress urinary incontinence (SUI).

primary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Reduction in 24-hour Pad Weight From Baseline to 6 Months
primary_outcome.description: Primary endpoint defined as at least a 50% reduction in 24-hour pad weight from baseline to 6 months (including dry as defined as a pad weight of less than 1.3 grams during the 6-month test), in which the percent of subjects with at least 50% reduction in 24-hour pad weight is compared to a performance goal of 50%.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Negative Cough Stress Test at 6 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Endpoint defined as a negative result at 6 months, as measured by the Cough Stress Test (CST), in which the percent of subjects with a negative CST is compared to a performance goal of 66%. The cough stress test was completed with the subject in the lithotomy and standing positions, filling bladder to maximum capacity with normal saline. The subject was then asked to cough 10 times and any leakage from the urethra was considered a positive test.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Improvement in Incontinence Via 3-Day Voiding Diary From Baseline to 6 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Endpoint defined as at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6-months, as measured by 3-Day Voiding Diary, in which the percent of subjects with at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6 months is compared to a performance goal of 50%. Subjects completed a 3-Day Voiding Diary of controlled urinations and the number and amount of leaks experienced.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Improvement in UDI-6 Score From Baseline to 6 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Endpoint defined as at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6 months, as measured by validated Urinary Distress Inventory Short Form (UDI-6), in which the percent of subjects with at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6 months is compared to a performance goal of 50%.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Improvement in IIQ-7 From Baseline to 6 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Endpoint defined as at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6 months, as measured by validated Incontinence Impact Questionnaire Short Form (IIQ-7), in which the percent of subjects with at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6 months is compared to a performance goal of 50%.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Responding "Very Much Better" or "Much Better" on PGI-I at 6 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Success defined as a response of "Very Much Better" or "Much Better" at 6 months, as measured by validated Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Reduction in 24-hour Pad Weight From Baseline to 12 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Success defined as at least a 50% reduction in 24-hour pad weight from baseline to 12 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With Negative Cough Stress Test at 12 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Success defined as a negative result at 12 months, as measured by the Cough Stress Test (CST). The cough stress test was completed with the subject in the lithotomy and standing positions, filling bladder to maximum capacity with normal saline. The subject was then asked to cough 10 times and any leakage from the urethra was considered a positive test.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Improvement in UDI-6 Score From Baseline to 12 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Success defined as at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 12 months, as measured by validated Urinary Distress Inventory Short Form (UDI-6)

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Improvement in IIQ-7 From Baseline to 12 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Success defined as at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 12 months, as measured by validated Incontinence Impact Questionnaire Short Form (IIQ-7)

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Patients Responding "Very Much Better" or "Much Better" on PGI-I at 12 Months
secondary_outcome.description: Success defined as a response of "Very Much Better" or "Much Better" at 12 months, as measured by validated Patient Global Impression of Improvement (PGI-I).

intervention.description: The Altis® SIS is a permanently implantable synthetic sling for females placed at the mid-urethra to provide a scaffold for tissue in-growth and support for stress urinary incontinence.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subject is female at least 18 years of age
- Subject is able and willing to complete all procedures and follow-up visits indicated in this protocol
- Subject has confirmed stress urinary incontinence (SUI) through cough stress test or urodynamics
- The subject has failed two non-invasive incontinence therapies (such as Kegel exercise, behavior modification, pad use, biofeedback, etc) for >6 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subject has an active urogenital infection or active skin infection in region of surgery
- Subject has confirmed Pelvic Organ Prolapse (POP) of Stage 2 or higher as determined by POP-Q prolapse grading
- Subject is having a concomitant pelvic floor procedure
- Subject has incontinence due to neurogenic causes (e.g. multiple sclerosis, spinal cord/brain injury, cerebrovascular accident, detrusor-external sphincter dyssynergia, Parkinson's disease, or similar conditions)
- Subject had a prior surgical SUI treatment
- Subject has undergone radiation or brachy therapy to treat pelvic cancer
- Subject has urge predominant incontinence
- Subject has an atonic bladder or a post void residual (PVR) consistently about 100cc
- Subject is pregnant and/or is planning to get pregnant in the future
- Subject has a contraindication to the surgical procedure or the Altis Instructions For Use (IFU)
- Subject is enrolled in a concurrent clinical trial of any treatment (drug or device) that could affect continence function without the sponsor's approval

overall_official.affiliation: University of Chicago, Chicago, IL, United States

facility.name: University of Illinois at Chicago - Department of Urology
Female Pelvic Medicine & Urogynecology Institute of Michigan
The University of Oklahoma Health Sciences Center

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Women with documented stress urinary incontinence (SUI) who met enrollment criteria

group.title: Altis® SIS
group.description: Participants implanted with Altis® Single Incision Sling

group.title: Altis® SIS
group.description: Participants implanted with Altis® Single Incision Sling

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Reduction in 24-hour Pad Weight From Baseline to 6 Months
outcome.description: Primary endpoint defined as at least a 50% reduction in 24-hour pad weight from baseline to 6 months (including dry as defined as a pad weight of less than 1.3 grams during the 6-month test), in which the percent of subjects with at least 50% reduction in 24-hour pad weight is compared to a performance goal of 50%.
outcome.population: Analysis was per protocol. 109 subjects were eligible for 6-month follow-up. 6 subjects missed either the visit or the pad weight test.

group.title: Altis SIS®
group.description: Participants implanted with Altis® Single Incision Sling

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Reduction in 24-hour Pad Weight From Baseline to 6 Months
measure.description: Primary endpoint defined as at least a 50% reduction in 24-hour pad weight from baseline to 6 months (including dry as defined as a pad weight of less than 1.3 grams during the 6-month test), in which the percent of subjects with at least 50% reduction in 24-hour pad weight is compared to a performance goal of 50%.
measure.population: Analysis was per protocol. 109 subjects were eligible for 6-month follow-up. 6 subjects missed either the visit or the pad weight test.

analysis.groups_desc: The final significance level is 0.04191 accounting for one interim analysis conducted at 80% of final information, thus a 95.81% Confidence Limit (CL) was used.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With Negative Cough Stress Test at 6 Months
outcome.description: Endpoint defined as a negative result at 6 months, as measured by the Cough Stress Test (CST), in which the percent of subjects with a negative CST is compared to a performance goal of 66%. The cough stress test was completed with the subject in the lithotomy and standing positions, filling bladder to maximum capacity with normal saline. The subject was then asked to cough 10 times and any leakage from the urethra was considered a positive test.
outcome.population: 109 subjects were eligible for 6-month follow-up. 6 subjects missed either the visit or the cough stress test.

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With at Least 50% Improvement in Incontinence Via 3-Day Voiding Diary From Baseline to 6 Months
outcome.description: Endpoint defined as at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6-months, as measured by 3-Day Voiding Diary, in which the percent of subjects with at least a 50% improvement from baseline to 6 months is compared to a performance goal of 50%. Subjects completed a 3-Day Voiding Diary of controlled urinations and the number and amount of leaks experienced.
outcome.population: 109 subjects were eligible for 6-month follow-up. 17 subjects either missed the visit or did not complete the 3-Day Voiding Diary.

event.description: Pelvic hematoma, resolved spontaneously in hospital
Subject underwent surgical revision due to symptoms
Classified as serious adverse event (SAE) due to subject withdrawal from study prior to further follow-up data collection

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
